Bats

few bolts left to spring.
Eleven men with Black and Blue jerseys will line up tomorrow's contest with but one aim in mind. They will not be playing a
defensive game and they will not be attempting to hold down the
score. They will be giving everything they have every minute with
but one sole object: to BEAT MARYLAND.
The student body is behind the team to a man. While the
Black and Blue jerseys are giving their all on the field, the Black
and Blue rooters will be giving their all in the stands. Both will
be satisfied with but one conclusion: a victory over Maryland.
Baltimore considers us "outclassed."
morrow!

We'll show them to-

VASSAR WOULDN'T
The foundations of Vassar's Honor System recently received a
severe _jolt when college authorities unwisely made smoking on the
campus, the rolling of stockings and other popular diversions of the
college female breaches of the Honor Code. Students persisted in
the practices and the enforcement of the Honor System at the
Northern college became a farce.
There was much agitation on the Vassar campus for the abolition of an Honor System that could not be enforced. The question
was submitted to the student body, which voted for retention of the
Code with the elimination of the objectionable prohibitions.
Such superficialities have no place in an Honor System. Will
man never learn that universally unpopular laws hold no power of
compulsion?

The News-Letter regrets to announce the temporary withdrawal of W. E. Thomsen from the Editorial Staff.

What a difference
just a few cents make !"

PennsylThe Virginians and- the
vania Serenaders. The committee's one concern is as to the kind
of financial backing to be received
from the student body.
Last year the actual ticket returns did not cover the expense.
The extra money was- raised by
having "tag days" throughout the
year preceding the affair. This
method was felt to be somewhat
unfair, some students who bought
tags received nothing in return
but a feeling that they had done
their duty toward Hopkins. So
this year a new plan has been
adopted.
Stamps on Sale

Stamps somewhat on the order
of the Government Thrift Stamps
are to be on sale periodically
throughout the year, beginning
the first of this week. At the end
of the year when the student buys
his ticket the stamps can be redeemable at their face value. Thus
it is possible to entirely pay for
a ticket before June Week actually comes. The price of the tickets has not been decided yet, but
it will certainly be affected by the
response of the students in tile
stamp selling drive.
"In conclusion," said Chairman
Norwood, "underclassmen must
understand that although the
Senior Class alone is financially
responsible for the project, it is
for the benefit of all the undergraduates, and they owe us their
support."

BARNSTORMERS ADOPT MUSIC FOR PRODUCTION
Continued from page 1

Wednesday at 4:15 in the Studio,
at which the attendance was larger
than had been expected. Besides
merely signing up for the production, the candidates were asked a
number of questions regarding previous experience in acting, singing
'and dancing. The answers revealed
an unusually encouraging percentage of candidates who had had previous experience in acting.
With a view towards obtaining
information about talent for the
cast, the Club suggested that the
candidates work up vaudeville
stunts of any kind at all, either
singly or in groups. These stunts
are to be given before the Club on
December 3 and 4. Any candidates
who are unable to originate their
own ideas for the acts are requested
to seek the advice of members of
the Club before giving up the idea.
It was emphasized at the meeting that candidates for the chorus
will not be compelled to do any
stunts. Those who do, however,
Will find their chances of obtaining
a berth in the cast greatly increased.

What Engineering
Owes to the Imagination
From An Argument Over
Watches Came KDKA
in the days when wireBACK
less was just beginning to

summoned to the office of Harry Phillips
Davis, Vice President of the company.

spread, Frank Conrad (now
Assistant Chief Engineer of the
Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Company)and another
official, happened to compare
watches, to see if it was time to
go back to work. Their watches
differed.

"Frank," said Mr. Davis, "I'm going to
close your radio station." His attention had
been attracted the night before to a simple
note in a full-page advertisement, which read,
"Mr. Conrad will send out phonograph music
this evening."

Unable to convince his friend
that his watch was right, Mr.
Conrad suddenly remembered
that the naval station at Arlington, Va., had just inaugurated
a system for sending out daily
time signals by radio. Just the thing to prove
his point!

You know the rest. In November, 1920,
"KDKA" was formally opened to send out
election _returns. It had received the first
license issued by Uncle Sam. Today over 500
broadcasting stations entertain and educate
millions of people each night, a wonderful
result from so insignificant an argument as
one oyer -watches.

So he built a simple set of receiving apparatus,
erected an aerial, and—you can imagine what
happened! He was badly bitten by the radio bug.
After proving to his satisfaction the accuracy of his
watch, he started experimenting with the transmission of music by radio, with good success.
He began sending out phonograph music from
his home, and attracted the attention of some of
the big department stores, that had installed radio
departments. They in turn, started advertising
Mr. Conrad's "musical evenings."
Then, one day, upon arriving at his desk, he was

Broadcasting Studio at Station KDKA, Westinghouse Electric Jo

Manufacturing Co. East Pittsburgh, Pa.

few bolts left to spring.
Eleven men with Black and Blue jerseys will line up tomorrow's contest with but one aim in mind. They will not be playing a
defensive game and they will not be attempting to hold down the
score. They will be giving everything they have every minute with
but one sole object: to BEAT MARYLAND.
The student body is behind the team to a man. While the
Black and Blue jerseys are giving their all on the field, the Black
and Blue rooters will be giving their all in the stands. Both will
be satisfied with but one conclusion: a victory over Maryland.
Baltimore considers us "outclassed."
morrow!

We'll show them to-

VASSAR WOULDN'T
The foundations of Vassar's Honor System recently received a
severe _jolt when college authorities unwisely made smoking on the
campus, the rolling of stockings and other popular diversions of the
college female breaches of the Honor Code. Students persisted in
the practices and the enforcement of the Honor System at the
Northern college became a farce.
There was much agitation on the Vassar campus for the abolition of an Honor System that could not be enforced. The question
was submitted to the student body, which voted for retention of the
Code with the elimination of the objectionable prohibitions.
Such superficialities have no place in an Honor System. Will
man never learn that universally unpopular laws hold no power of
compulsion?

The News-Letter regrets to announce the temporary withdrawal of W. E. Thomsen from the Editorial Staff.

What a difference
just a few cents make !"

PennsylThe Virginians and- the
vania Serenaders. The committee's one concern is as to the kind
of financial backing to be received
from the student body.
Last year the actual ticket returns did not cover the expense.
The extra money was- raised by
having "tag days" throughout the
year preceding the affair. This
method was felt to be somewhat
unfair, some students who bought
tags received nothing in return
but a feeling that they had done
their duty toward Hopkins. So
this year a new plan has been
adopted.
Stamps on Sale

Stamps somewhat on the order
of the Government Thrift Stamps
are to be on sale periodically
throughout the year, beginning
the first of this week. At the end
of the year when the student buys
his ticket the stamps can be redeemable at their face value. Thus
it is possible to entirely pay for
a ticket before June Week actually comes. The price of the tickets has not been decided yet, but
it will certainly be affected by the
response of the students in tile
stamp selling drive.
"In conclusion," said Chairman
Norwood, "underclassmen must
understand that although the
Senior Class alone is financially
responsible for the project, it is
for the benefit of all the undergraduates, and they owe us their
support."

BARNSTORMERS ADOPT MUSIC FOR PRODUCTION
Continued from page 1

Wednesday at 4:15 in the Studio,
at which the attendance was larger
than had been expected. Besides
merely signing up for the production, the candidates were asked a
number of questions regarding previous experience in acting, singing
'and dancing. The answers revealed
an unusually encouraging percentage of candidates who had had previous experience in acting.
With a view towards obtaining
information about talent for the
cast, the Club suggested that the
candidates work up vaudeville
stunts of any kind at all, either
singly or in groups. These stunts
are to be given before the Club on
December 3 and 4. Any candidates
who are unable to originate their
own ideas for the acts are requested
to seek the advice of members of
the Club before giving up the idea.
It was emphasized at the meeting that candidates for the chorus
will not be compelled to do any
stunts. Those who do, however,
Will find their chances of obtaining
a berth in the cast greatly increased.

What Engineering
Owes to the Imagination
From An Argument Over
Watches Came KDKA
in the days when wireBACK
less was just beginning to

summoned to the office of Harry Phillips
Davis, Vice President of the company.

spread, Frank Conrad (now
Assistant Chief Engineer of the
Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Company)and another
official, happened to compare
watches, to see if it was time to
go back to work. Their watches
differed.

"Frank," said Mr. Davis, "I'm going to
close your radio station." His attention had
been attracted the night before to a simple
note in a full-page advertisement, which read,
"Mr. Conrad will send out phonograph music
this evening."

Unable to convince his friend
that his watch was right, Mr.
Conrad suddenly remembered
that the naval station at Arlington, Va., had just inaugurated
a system for sending out daily
time signals by radio. Just the thing to prove
his point!

You know the rest. In November, 1920,
"KDKA" was formally opened to send out
election _returns. It had received the first
license issued by Uncle Sam. Today over 500
broadcasting stations entertain and educate
millions of people each night, a wonderful
result from so insignificant an argument as
one oyer -watches.

So he built a simple set of receiving apparatus,
erected an aerial, and—you can imagine what
happened! He was badly bitten by the radio bug.
After proving to his satisfaction the accuracy of his
watch, he started experimenting with the transmission of music by radio, with good success.
He began sending out phonograph music from
his home, and attracted the attention of some of
the big department stores, that had installed radio
departments. They in turn, started advertising
Mr. Conrad's "musical evenings."
Then, one day, upon arriving at his desk, he was
